TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {997=Because of the Gulf Stream, the climate in Norway is noticeably warmer than what would otherwise be expected at such high latitude. Summers can be moderately warm (up to 30 degrees Celsius), even in northern areas, but only for limited periods. The length of the winter and amount of snow varies around the country. In the north there is more snow and winters are dark; on the southern and western coasts, winters are moderate and rainy, while further inland the temperature can get below -25 degrees Celsius. March, April, October and November tend to be the rainiest months. Snow usually starts to fall in October/November in the northern areas (and in higher altitudes) and generally melts by the end of April. The Northern Lights are visible from parts of Norway, with September to April usually presenting the optimal conditions for viewing.}
textBeforeTable: Recommended reading Further reading 7. Please ask and receive permission before taking photos of people, including children. 6. Refrain from supporting businesses that exploit or abuse endangered animals. 5. Shop for locally made products. Supporting local artisans helps keep traditional crafts alive. 4. Learn some local language and don't be afraid to use it - simple greetings will help break the ice. 3. Always dispose of litter thoughtfully, including cigarette butts. 2. For environmental reasons, try to avoid buying bottled water. Instead, fill a reusable water bottle or canteen with tap or filtered water. 1. Be considerate of Norway’s customs, traditions, religion and culture. Top responsible travel tips for Norway Intrepid is committed to travelling in a way that is respectful of local people, their culture, local economies and the environment. It's important to remember that what may be acceptable behaviour, dress and language in your own country, may not be appropriate in another. Please keep this in mind while travelling. Norway Travel Tips Responsible Travel also provides useful health information: Go to:
